attributes.alt: Book cover for Imagine by Juan Felipe Herrera and illustrated by Lauren Castillo. The cover art shows a boy outside looking up at the moon and the stars at night.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, encourage movement, and introduce new vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What does Juan like to do?
Read for enjoyment and understanding. Call attention to how each page of the poem begins with the word “If” and ends with “Imagine.”
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences; Write uppercase and lowercase letters.
Join two or more words to create a compound word.
Use information to describe; Relate own experiences to those in books.
Communicate nonverbally with peers who speak a different language.
Use perception to guide movement through space and interactions with objects and people.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Challenge children to engage in teamwork.
Provide an opportunity for kinesthetic learning by having children form letter shapes with their bodies.
What do you imagine as you read your book?
Act out something Juan does to help his Mamá on the farm.
Can you guess what a tadpole turns into when it grows up?
Can you finish this sentence? “When I play outside, I like to  .”
Can you draw a picture of where you like to play outdoors?
What’s your favorite letter? Can you find things in your center that begin with that letter?
Can you build a farm in California?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Imagine by Juan Felipe Herrera and illustrated by Lauren Castillo. The cover art shows a boy outside looking up at the moon and the stars at night.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to practice the
Mind Builder and introduce related vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice things Juan does and practices that connect to the Mind Builder.
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Understand and use a growing number of personal and possessive pronouns.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Connect to the book by reminding children that Juan liked to learn and practice new things.
Allow children to showcase their skills in a fun talent show.
Inspire confidence in children with a post-show discussion about their own abilities.
What is your character learning in your book?
Act out something new that you learned how to do! Can you give us a clue?
Let’s count to three in English and Spanish: one/uno, two/dos, three/tres.
Make a You Did It! card for a friend who learned to do something new.
Can you make a picture to go with the card?
Can you build the letters of the alphabet using blocks?
Can you work with a friend to build something tall?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Imagine by Juan Felipe Herrera and illustrated by Lauren Castillo. The cover art shows a boy outside looking up at the moon and the stars at night.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Language skill
What happens after Juan learns English?
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Communicate nonverbally with peers who speak a different language.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment, such as hills, rivers, roads, lakes, and familiar buildings.
Identify flags of the United States and of home state.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Introduce children to the concept of nonverbal communication.
Engage children in a game of charades! Help them act out scenes from
How do the characters talk to each other in your book?
Show how you would make friends with someone if you didn’t speak the same language.
Let’s count how many stripes are on the U.S. flag.
in Spanish sounds like the word
in English. Can you write the words
Work together to make a Welcome Banner for your classroom! Decorate it with the words
. Can you find other ways to say “hello”?
How can you make the letter
with your body? Work with a friend or two if you need to.

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas. The chart says, I want to . . . Learn to tie my shoes. Drive a fast train. Be a doctor. Make colorful art.
Book cover for Imagine by Juan Felipe Herrera and illustrated by Lauren Castillo. The cover art shows a boy outside looking up at the moon and the stars at night.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about things we want to do, and introduce vocabulary words
Start Story Time by connecting the texts
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question:
Use information to describe; Relate own experiences to those in books.
Understand and use a growing number of personal and possessive pronouns.
Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Have children think about something they want to do or learn.
Engage children in pretend play in which they role-play what they want to be when they grow up.
Talk about the importance of hard work and practice.
What is something that you want to learn to do?
Think about what you could teach a friend to do. Can you show what you would do?
Together let’s count to ten by ones and then by twos!
Write or tell three things you want to do. Put them in order of what you would do first, second, and third.
Think like an artist. Can you create a picture of what you want to do first?
Write the first letter of your first name as big as you can, then as small as you can.
Can you build a city with blocks? Compare it to the city where Juan went to school. Does it have tall, bending buildings?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Imagine by Juan Felipe Herrera and illustrated by Lauren Castillo. The cover art shows a boy outside looking up at the moon and the stars at night.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children act out given situations involving patience, and introduce them to new vocabulary
How do you use your imagination?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Relate own experiences to those in books; Share and repeat the details in a text.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
What can happen when you imagine?
Encourage children to explain their choices.
, Juan says “imagine what you could do.” What is something that you imagine you could do?
Pretend you are outside on a starry night. What do you see in your imagination?
Can you use your body to make a shadow on the floor or wall?
Imagine three words that make you smile. Can you say or write them down?
Create a picture from your imagination to go with your words.
Can you read an Alphabet Book to a stuffed animal?
Collect building materials and create something one-of-a-kind from your imagination.

Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Combine words to make a compound word.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Show self-awareness and can express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Engage in various forms of nonverbal communication with those who do not speak their native language.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.

Show self-awareness and can express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Show a reasonable opinion of own abilities and limitations.

Respond to different musical styles through movement and play.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Make inferences and predictions about text.

Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
